text:
UKIP's knives, knights and knaves: Mirror Politics morning briefing UKIP is plunged into civil war as Nigel Farage demands its sole MP is booted out of the party Share Comments By Jason Beattie 08:43, 28 FEB 2017 News Opinion Nigel Farage is alleged to be angling for a knighthood (Photo: Getty) However bad Labour’s problems are at the moment the party can take some consolation they are not as catastrophic as those of UKIP.
Having achieved their one policy objective, the Kippers are wandering on the fringes of the political debate without a clear role.
They are cash-strapped, led by a gold-medal winning fantasist and riven with infighting.
Paul Nuttall’s ambitions to recast UKIP as an alternative to Labour ended in humiliation on the streets of Stoke , while Theresa May’s hard Brexit has seen its right-wing supporters peel off to the Tories.
Nigel Farage is now calling for the party’s sole MP, Douglas Carswell, to be thrown out of the party.
One of Carswell’s alleged offences is not to have lobbied with sufficient vigour for needy Nigel to get an honour.
Nigel Farage has called for Douglas Carswell to be booted out of UKIP (Photo: Getty) It tells you a lot about Farage, the supposed champion of the people and scourge of the establishment, that he craves so desperately the recognition of a knighthood.
In a speech last night John Major placed himself at the forefront of the Brexit resistance .
The former Prime Minister has a mild manner but his message was delivered with an iron brush dipped in scouring powder.
He was scathing about almost everything, whether the delusions of the Brexiteers or Theresa May’s leaden-footed diplomacy.
There was a distinct whiff of gun smoke from ancient Tory battles in some of his words, not least his puncturing of the “over-optimistic” promises peddled by leavers on how Britain can flourish outside the EU.
Nor was he impressed with his successor’s negotiating strategy, saying “a little more charm, and a lot less cheap rhetoric” should be deployed when the talks with the EU begin in earnest.
Sir John Major angered Brexiteers with his speech (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Those who champion leaving the EU have dismissed his offering as the grumblings of a sore Remainer. Others accused him of being unduly pessimistic.
Though it was telling his critics resorted to personal attacks rather than confront his arguments.
Some of Sir John’s criticisms deserve consideration.
He was especially acute about the dangers of turning Britain into a tax haven if we cannot get the deal we want.
“There is a choice to be made, a price to be paid; we cannot move to a radical enterprise economy without moving away from a welfare state,” he said, pointing out the people who are likely to be worst affected are those who voted to leave Europe in the belief it might improve their lives.
This is an argument many wish Labour would make more forcefully.
Sir John also cautioned about the difficulties of trying to achieve a sector by sector deal with the EU.
This, he noted, meant picking winners and losers.
Co-incidentally, the boss of Nissan UK is up before the International Trade select committee today where he will be quizzed about the agreement, as yet unpublished, which persuaded the firm to continue manufacturing in the UK.
The Commons kicks off today with Treasury questions.
The Chancellor Philip Hammond yesterday slipped out that he wants Government departments to draw up plans for further cuts of up to 6% from 2019.
So much for the end of austerity.
The architect of austerity, George Osborne, is one of the speakers at the British Chambers of Commerce conference today.
Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell and Business Secretary Greg Clark are also addressing the gathering.
Mr McDonnell is expected to outline plans for a £500million lifeline to support small companies hit by the rise in business rates .
